original_title: Sri Lanka’s shares slip in mid day trade across the board on debt restructuring comments
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s shares edged down in mid day trade on Wednesday across the board after comments made President Ranil Wickremesinghe channeled after comments made on debt restructuring and the stock market.

“Investors are prompted to selling off their shares across the board, which is bringing the index down. The market is coming down on the President’s address, the stance of debt restructuring, wait and see approaches have been adopted,” an analyst said.
The main All Share Price Index slipped 0.73 percent or 66.31 pts to 9,025.41, while the most liquid index S&P SL20 was down 0.58 percent or 15.25 points to 2,631.23.

Domestic debt also has to be restructured, but no final decision has been reached, President Wickremesinghe said in Parliament, while presenting the International Monetary Fund deal to the Parliament.
“The more a wait-and-see approach is adopted, the lower the turnover gets,” the analyst said.

Sri Lanka’s Governor, Nandalal Weerasinghe, stated that the country would not restructure Treasury bills outside of central bank holdings and would engage with major T-bond holders for voluntary ‘optimization.’
The market generated a slow turnover of 550 million rupees at 1200 hours.
Top losers during trade was Commercial Bank, DFCC Bank and LOLC. (Colombo/April27/2023)
